It focuses on the chemical processes that company and industrial sectors utilize to develop products, including dyes, fertilizers, plastics, detergents, petrochemicals, and pharmaceuticals, on a mass scale. Industrial chemistry is crucial for advances in technology and its applications often require the optimization and scaling up of chemical reactions to serve different industries. The field integrates concepts from both pure and applied chemistry and emphasizes energy efficiency, sustainability, and economic viability.

Subtopics
  • Chemical Process Engineering: Understanding and designing chemical processes and plants for large-scale production.
  • Material Synthesis: Methods for producing materials like polymers and composites efficiently.
  • Catalysis: Study and application of catalysts to accelerate industrial chemical reactions.
  • Environmental Chemistry: Developing eco-friendly processes and minimizing environmental impact.
  • Quality Control and Analysis: Techniques for ensuring the consistency and quality of chemical products.
  • Petrochemicals: Conversion of oil and natural gas into petrochemical products.
  • Pharmaceuticals: Chemical synthesis and production methods for drugs and active pharmaceutical ingredients.
  • Sustainable Chemistry: Application of sustainable practices and resources to improve industrial chemical processes.
  • Energy Production: Chemical processes related to energy generation and storage, including batteries and biofuels.
  • Industrial Biochemistry: Use of biochemical processes in industrial production, particularly in biotechnology and pharmaceuticals.
 

Colour chemistry

Colour chemistry is a specialized branch of chemistry that deals with the study of coloured compounds and materials. It explores how chemical structures interact with light to produce colours, the development of dyes and pigments, and the applications of coloured substances in various industries. This field combines aspects of organic chemistry, inorganic chemistry, and physics to understand the properties that dictate colour formation, stability, and modification. Colour chemistry is crucial in the creation of materials such as paints, textiles, inks, and cosmetics, and also plays a role in the development of technologies such as display screens and sensors.

Subtopics
  • Molecular structure and light absorption
  • Synthesis of dyes and pigments
  • Colour fastness and durability in materials
  • Role of transition metals in colouring compounds
  • Organic and inorganic pigments
  • Influence of pH on colour
  • Environmental impact and sustainability in colour production
  • Spectroscopy and analytical methods for colour analysis
  • Applications of colour chemistry in industry (e.g., textiles, printing, food)
 

Inorganic chemistry

Inorganic chemistry is a branch of chemistry that focuses on the study of inorganic compounds, which include metals, minerals, and organometallic compounds. Unlike organic chemistry, which is dedicated to carbon-containing compounds, inorganic chemistry explores substances that do not fall into the category of organic molecules. This field covers a diverse range of materials, encompassing not only the synthesis and behavior of inorganic substances but also their application in various industries. Inorganic chemists investigate elements and compounds across the periodic table, excluding the realm of carbon-based life but including all other elements and their myriad combinations. This discipline plays a critical role in the development of new materials, catalysts, and understanding of mineral processes in nature.

Subtopics
  • Coordination Chemistry: Study of coordination compounds and complexes, focusing on the interactions of metal ions with ligands.
  • Bioinorganic Chemistry: Examination of the roles of metals in biology, including metalloproteins and metal ion transport in organisms.
  • Solid State Chemistry: Exploration of the structure, properties, and synthesis of solid materials.
  • Organometallic Chemistry: Research on compounds containing metal-carbon bonds and their applications in catalysis and industrial processes.
  • Main Group Chemistry: Investigation of the properties and reactions of the main group elements, such as alkali metals, alkaline earth metals, and halogens.
  • Transition Metal Chemistry: Study of the chemistry of transition metals, their compounds, and various oxidation states.
  • Industrial Inorganic Chemistry: Analysis of the production and use of inorganic substances in industries, including fertilizers, pigments, and cleaning agents.
  • Synthesis and Reactivity of Inorganic Compounds: Strategies for creating and characterizing new inorganic molecules and materials.
  • Materials Chemistry: Study of the design, synthesis, and application of new inorganic materials with specific functions or uses.
 

Structural chemistry

Structural chemistry is the study of the spatial arrangements of atoms in molecules and compounds and how this arrangement affects their properties and reactions. It involves the investigation of the three-dimensional structures of chemical compounds using various methods such as X-ray crystallography, nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, and electron microscopy. Understanding molecular geometry is crucial in predicting the behavior and interaction of molecules, which has applications in fields ranging from drug design to materials science. Structural chemistry intertwines with other areas of chemistry and physics to provide insights into atomic and molecular level interactions.

Subtopics
  • Molecular geometry and bonding theories
  • Crystallography and diffraction methods
  • Spectroscopy techniques for structural determination
  • Computational modeling of molecular structures
  • Structure-activity relationships in biochemistry
  • Nanostructures and materials chemistry
  • Conformational analysis and stereochemistry
 

Crystallography

Crystallography is the branch of chemistry that explores the arrangement of atoms within a crystalline solid. By using techniques such as X-ray diffraction, crystallography allows scientists to determine the three-dimensional structure of complex molecules and materials. This understanding is crucial in fields ranging from mineralogy and metallurgy to biology and materials science, as it provides fundamental insights into the structural properties that dictate the behavior and characteristics of materials.

Subtopics
  • X-ray Crystallography: Examining the atomic and molecular structure of crystals via X-ray diffraction patterns.
  • Neutron Diffraction: A crystallography technique using neutron scattering to determine the atomic and/or magnetic structure of a crystal.
  • Electron Crystallography: Using electron microscopes and electron diffraction to define crystal structures.
  • Protein Crystallography: Studying the molecular structure of proteins and other biological macromolecules in crystalline form.
  • Crystallographic Symmetry: Analyzing symmetry and periodicity in crystal structures.
  • Computational Crystallography: Utilizing software and algorithms to simulate and solve crystal structures.
  • Crystallographic Databases: Repositories storing crystal structures for academic and industrial research.
  • Chemical and Biological Applications: Application of crystallography to the development of pharmaceuticals, novel materials, and catalysts.
  • Crystallographic Errors and Limitations: Understanding the potential inaccuracies in crystallographic measurements and data interpretation.
  • Historical Development: Evolution of crystallography from the early studies of crystals to modern advanced techniques.
 

Environmental chemistry

Environmental chemistry is the scientific study of the chemical and biochemical phenomena that occur in natural places. It is an interdisciplinary field that combines elements of chemistry and environmental science to understand the interactions between chemicals and the natural environment. The focus of environmental chemistry is on understanding the sources, reactions, transport, effects, and fates of chemical species in the air, soil, and water, and the impact of human activities on these natural processes. This field is essential for assessing pollution levels, understanding ecological impacts, and developing sustainable practices to protect our environment.

Subtopics
  • Chemical Pollutants in the Environment: Study of various pollutants including heavy metals, pesticides, and industrial chemicals, and their impacts.
  • Biogeochemical Cycles: Exploration of natural cycles such as the carbon, nitrogen, and sulfur cycles, and the role of pollutants in altering these cycles.
  • Water Chemistry and Pollution: Analysis of chemical components in water bodies, water quality assessments, and effects of contaminants like nitrates and phosphates.
  • Atmospheric Chemistry and Air Pollution: Investigation of chemical composition of the atmosphere, sources of air pollutants, and phenomena such as acid rain and ozone depletion.
  • Soil Chemistry and Contamination: Examination of soil properties related to chemical composition, soil contaminants, and strategies for remediation.
  • Toxicology and Risk Assessment: Study of the harmful effects of chemicals on human health and ecosystems, including the development of risk assessment models.
  • Green Chemistry: Exploration of chemical processes that minimize environmental impact, focusing on sustainable and eco-friendly chemical production.
 

Marine chemistry

Marine chemistry is a branch of chemistry that focuses on the chemical composition and processes occurring in the Earth's oceans and seas. It explores the intricate interactions between seawater's chemical constituents, both organic and inorganic, and the surrounding atmosphere, geological formations, and marine organisms. Marine chemists study various elements, compounds, and reactions to understand and predict changes in oceanic environments, including phenomena like acidification, nutrient cycling, carbon sequestration, and pollutant dispersion. This field is crucial for environmental monitoring and sustainable management of marine resources.

Subtopics
  • Salinity and its variations
  • Oceanic water cycles and evaporation
  • Chemical interactions with marine geology
  • Effects of climate change on ocean chemistry
  • Carbon cycle dynamics in marine environments
  • Nutrient distribution and assimilation in ocean waters
  • Ocean acidification and its impact on marine life
  • Pollutant chemical analysis and tracing
  • Biochemical processes of marine organisms
  • Interaction between the hydrosphere and atmosphere
 

Medicinal chemistry

Medicinal chemistry is an interdisciplinary field at the intersection of chemistry, pharmacology, and various biological specialties. It focuses on the design, synthesis, and development of pharmaceutical agents, or bio-active molecules. The goal of medicinal chemistry is to discover, develop, and improve the efficacy and safety of chemical compounds intended for therapeutic use. The discipline involves the study of drug composition, mechanisms of action, chemical properties, and the optimization of drugs to improve potency while reducing side effects. Advanced medicinal chemistry combines sophisticated techniques such as computational drug design and high-throughput screening to identify promising drug candidates.

Subtopics
  • Drug Design and Discovery: Methods for identifying new therapeutic candidates, including rational drug design and combinatorial chemistry.
  • Bioinformatics and Computational Chemistry: Use of technology and computational methods to simulate drug interactions and optimize molecular structures.
  • Pharmacodynamics and Pharmacokinetics: Study of the effects of drugs on biological systems and the movement of drugs within the body.
  • Structure-Activity Relationships (SAR): Analysis of the relationship between a drug's chemical structure and its biological activity.
  • Synthesis of Therapeutic Agents: Development of chemical methods for the synthesis of medicinal compounds.
  • Lead Optimization and Development: Enhancement of the desired properties of drug candidates through modifications.
  • Toxicology and Safety Assessment: Evaluation of the safety profiles and potential side effects of drug candidates.
  • Regulatory Science: Understanding of regulatory requirements and processes involved in drug approval and marketing.
 

Pharmaceutical chemistry

Pharmaceutical chemistry is a branch of chemistry focused on the design, development, and analysis of drugs. It encompasses the creation of new chemical entities for therapeutic use, development of processes for drug synthesis, and the study of interactions between chemical compounds and biological systems. It plays a critical role in the development of new medications and ensures the safety and efficacy of pharmaceutical products through rigorous testing and analysis.

Subtopics
  • Drug Design and Discovery: The process of identifying new active chemical compounds and preparing synthetic strategies for novel drugs.
  • Medicinal Chemistry: The study of chemical compounds and their biological activities to optimize therapeutic drug compounds.
  • Analytical Techniques: Methods used to analyze chemical compounds, purity, stability, and identification in pharmaceutical contexts, such as HPLC, mass spectrometry, and NMR spectroscopy.
  • Drug Synthesis and Development: Procedures and methods used to synthesize and develop chemical compounds into viable pharmaceutical drugs.
  • Pharmacokinetics and Pharmacodynamics: Study of how drugs move through and affect the body, influencing the design and dosing regimen of pharmaceuticals.
  • Regulatory Affairs: Involves understanding the regulatory requirements and processes for drug approval and compliance with the law.
 

Organic chemistry

Organic chemistry is a branch of chemistry that focuses on the study of the structure, properties, composition, reactions, and preparation of carbon-containing compounds. These compounds include hydrocarbons and their derivatives. Organic chemistry plays a crucial role in the development of pharmaceutical drugs, petrochemicals, plastics, food, explosives, and paints, significantly impacting various industrial applications and the global economy. It involves understanding the behavior of organic molecules through the exploration of functional groups, stereochemistry, reaction mechanisms, and synthesis techniques.

Subtopics
  • Structure and Bonding:
  • Functional Groups:
  • Stereochemistry:
  • Reaction Mechanisms:
  • Reagents and Synthesis:
  • Spectroscopy and Structural Determination:
  • Biological Organic Chemistry:
  • Environmental and Industrial Applications:
 

Organometallic chemistry

Organometallic chemistry is a branch of chemistry that focuses on compounds containing bonds between carbon and a metal. It involves studying the synthesis, structure, reactivity, and applications of organometallic compounds, which play a crucial role in both academic research and industrial applications. These compounds often serve as catalysts in chemical reactions, including polymerization and hydrogenation, and are pivotal in processes like the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis and Olefin metathesis. The study also explores the mechanisms of reactions involving organometallic compounds, contributing to the development of new catalysts and expanding the understanding of chemical bonding and reactivity.

Subtopics
  • Metal Carbonyls: Study of complexes formed between metals and carbon monoxide.
  • Catalytic Cycles: Examination of organometallic compounds used in catalysis.
  • Organolithium Compounds: Exploration of applications and reactivity of lithium-based organometallics.
  • Grignard Reagents: Understanding the use of organomagnesium compounds in synthesis.
  • Transition Metal Compounds: Analysis of transition metals' role in organometallic chemistry.
  • Bonding and Structure: Investigation of the types of chemical bonds in organometallic compounds.
  • Applications in Industry: Overview of how organometallic compounds are used in industrial processes.
  • Mechanistic Studies: Detailed study of reaction mechanisms involving organometallic compounds.
  • CH Activation: Exploration of how organometallic chemistry facilitates the activation of carbon-hydrogen bonds.
 

Polymer chemistry

Polymer chemistry is a branch of chemistry focused on the study of polymers, which are large molecules composed of repeated subunits called monomers. It involves the analysis of chemical properties, synthesis, and applications of both natural and synthetic polymers. The field explores various types of polymerization processes, molecular structures, and how these impact material properties like elasticity, durability, and thermal stability. Polymer chemistry is foundational to developing new materials with specific characteristics for use in industries such as plastics, textiles, medicine, and electronics.

Subtopics
  • Polymer Synthesis: Methods of forming polymers, including addition polymerization and condensation polymerization.
  • Types of Polymers: Thermoplastics, thermosetting polymers, elastomers, and biopolymers.
  • Polymer Structure: Understanding the molecular architecture, such as linear, branched, and cross-linked structures.
  • Polymer Properties: Physical, chemical, and mechanical properties that define the behavior and utility of polymers.
  • Polymer Characterization: Techniques like spectroscopy, chromatography, and microscopy used to analyze polymers.
  • Polymer Applications: The use of polymers in various industries, including healthcare, automotive, aerospace, and consumer products.
  • Environmental Impact: The study of biodegradable polymers, recycling processes, and sustainability considerations in polymer production.
 

Bio-organic chemistry

Bio-organic chemistry is an interdisciplinary field that combines elements of organic chemistry and biochemistry to study the role and behavior of organic molecules within biological systems. This area of research specifically focuses on understanding the structure, function, and mechanism of biologically active molecules, including enzymes, nucleic acids, carbohydrates, lipids, and small organic compounds involved in cellular processes. By analyzing the chemical interactions and transformations that occur in biological contexts, bio-organic chemistry provides valuable insights into the molecular underpinnings of life and aids in the development of new pharmaceuticals, diagnostic tools, and biomaterials.

Subtopics
  • Enzyme Mechanisms: Examination of the catalytic processes and active site dynamics of enzymes, which facilitate biochemical reactions.
  • Nucleic Acid Chemistry: Study of the structure and function of DNA and RNA, including replication, transcription, and translation processes.
  • Carbohydrate Chemistry: Analysis of the structure and function of sugars and their role in energy storage and structural components of cells.
  • Lipid Chemistry: Investigation into the chemical properties of lipids and their roles in cell membranes and energy storage.
  • Natural Products Chemistry: Exploration of biologically active compounds derived from natural sources and their applications.
  • Peptide and Protein Chemistry: Study of the synthesis, structure, and function of peptides and proteins in biological systems.
  • Synthetic Methods in Bio-organic Chemistry: Development of novel organic synthesis techniques for creating biologically relevant molecules.
  • Chemical Biology: Use of chemical approaches to study and manipulate biological systems for scientific inquiry and therapeutic development.
 

Petrochemical chemistry

Petrochemical chemistry focuses on the chemical processes and compounds derived from petroleum and natural gas. As a branch of chemistry, it explores the transformation of raw hydrocarbon compounds into more valuable products such as plastics, synthetic rubber, solvents, and fertilizers. This field is integral to the petrochemical industry, driving innovations for more efficient, sustainable, and economically viable methods of processing fossil fuels into chemical intermediates and consumer products. Understanding the molecular structure and reactivity of hydrocarbons, as well as the applications of catalysts in petrochemical reactions, is critical for advancements in this area.

Subtopics
  • Hydrocarbon Chemistry: Examines the structure, reactivity, and transformation of hydrocarbon molecules.
  • Industrial Catalysis: Focuses on the catalysts used to accelerate chemical reactions in the production of petrochemical products.
  • Polymerization Processes: Involves the chemical reactions that convert small molecules, known as monomers, into polymers like plastics.
  • Refining and Distillation Techniques: Covers the methods used to separate and purify different components from crude oil.
  • Environmental Impact and Sustainability: Evaluates the ecological footprint of petrochemical processes and seeks greener alternatives.
  • Gas-to-Liquids (GTL) Technology: Studies the conversion of natural gas into liquid hydrocarbons for various applications.
  • Synthetic Organic Chemistry: Involves the construction of complex chemical compounds from simple organic molecules.
 

Biomolecular chemistry

Biomolecular chemistry is a branch of chemistry that focuses on the study of molecules found in living organisms. This includes the structure, function, and interactions of biological molecules such as proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates, and lipids. By understanding these molecules at a chemical level, researchers can discover how biological processes operate and how certain changes can affect organism health and disease development. This field intersects with biochemistry and molecular biology and is crucial for advancements in biotechnology and medicine.

Subtopics
  • Proteins and Enzymes: Structure and function, enzyme kinetics, and mechanism of action.
  • Nucleic Acids: DNA and RNA structure, replication, transcription, and translation.
  • Carbohydrates: Structure and function in cellular processes, and role in energy storage.
  • Lipids: Formation of biological membranes, signaling pathways, and energy storage.
  • Metabolism: Biochemical pathways and energy production.
  • Molecular Recognition: Interactions between biomolecules, including ligand binding and specificity.
  • Chemical Biology: Use of chemical tools to study biological systems.
  • Biomolecular Interactions: Study of interactions between different biomolecules.
  • Biocatalysis: Design and application of enzymes for chemical reactions.
 

Physical chemistry

Physical chemistry is a branch of chemistry that focuses on understanding the physical principles underlying chemical interactions and reactions. It combines concepts from physics, such as thermodynamics and quantum mechanics, to explain how chemical systems behave. This field is essential for developing new technologies and materials, understanding biological processes, and improving industrial processes. Physical chemists study the kinetics and dynamics of reactions, the properties and behavior of liquids, solids, and gases, and the ways in which energy is exchanged during chemical reactions.

Subtopics
  • Thermodynamics: Study of energy transformations and equilibria in chemical systems.
  • Quantum chemistry: Application of quantum mechanics to molecular and atomic structures.
  • Reaction kinetics: Analysis of the rates of chemical reactions and the factors affecting them.
  • Statistical mechanics: Explanation of macroscopic properties of materials based on molecular behavior.
  • Spectroscopy: Use of light absorption or emission to study molecular properties and reactions.
  • Surface chemistry: Investigation of physical and chemical phenomena occurring at the interface of different phases.
  • Electrochemistry: Study of chemical reactions that involve the transfer of electrons and their applications.
  • Computational chemistry: Use of computer simulations and models to solve chemical problems.
 

Analytical chemistry

Analytical chemistry is a branch of chemistry involved with the study and use of instruments and methods to separate, identify, and quantify matter. It plays a critical role in providing information on the composition and structure of substances, contributing significantly to fields such as pharmaceuticals, environmental science, and food safety. Analytical chemistry combines both classical and modern methods, including chromatography, spectroscopy, and electrochemical analysis, to obtain precise and accurate measurements of chemical substances in various matrices. By employing qualitative and quantitative analyses, analytical chemistry facilitates a deep understanding of chemical compounds and reactions, proving indispensable in research and industry.

Subtopics
  • Qualitative Analysis: Techniques to determine the composition of unknown substances.
  • Quantitative Analysis: Methods to quantify the exact amount of material present in a mixture.
  • Chromatography: Techniques for separating mixtures into their components.
  • Spectroscopy: Methods utilizing the interaction of light with matter.
  • Electrochemical Analysis: Techniques analyzing the chemical properties by measuring electrical signals.
  • Mass Spectrometry: A method to determine mass and structure of molecules.
  • Sample Preparation: Procedures for preparing samples for analysis.
  • Instrumental Techniques: Use of specialized equipment for precise measurement.
  • Method Validation: Process of confirming that the analytical procedure employed for tests is suitable for its intended purpose.
  • Data Analysis and Interpretation: Tools and methods for interpreting complex data collected during analysis.
 

Chemistry not elsewhere classified

This area of chemistry covers experimental, theoretical, or practical studies that do not fall under the standard branches such as organic, inorganic, analytical, or physical chemistry. It allows for the exploration of unconventional or emerging chemical domains, integrating concepts from various scientific fields. This could include interdisciplinary research leveraging computational methods, new material synthesis, novel reaction mechanisms, or advancements in chemical technology that transcend traditional categorizations. Due to its broad nature, chemistry not elsewhere classified often leads to innovative approaches and discoveries that challenge existing chemical paradigms.

Subtopics
  • Interdisciplinary Chemistry: Studies that merge principles and methods from other scientific disciplines with chemistry, leading to new cross-disciplinary insights.
  • Computational Chemistry: Development and application of computational methods and simulations to solve chemical problems that do not strictly fall under conventional sub-disciplines.
  • Novel Material Synthesis: Creation of new materials that do not fit into the typical categories of materials science, often with unique properties or functions.
  • Innovative Reaction Mechanisms: Exploration of non-traditional processes and pathways for chemical reactions that have not been extensively classified or studied.
  • Advanced Chemical Technology: New techniques and technologies in chemistry that push the boundaries of what current subfields typically cover.
  • Emerging Chemical Theories: Development and discussion of new theoretical frameworks that potentially lead to redefining chemical concepts or understanding.
  • Environmental and Sustainable Chemistry: Focus on innovative methods and approaches in chemistry aimed at solving environmental issues and achieving sustainability, often cutting across several subfields.
 

Materials science

Materials science

Materials science is an interdisciplinary field focused on the design and discovery of new materials, primarily solids. The field is centered around understanding the properties, performance, and processing of materials to create solutions that improve technologies and products. By studying the atomic structure and composition of materials, scientists and engineers can derive relationships between microstructure and properties, which influences how materials behave under various conditions. The discipline intersects with physics, chemistry, and engineering, playing a critical role in innovations within electronics, manufacturing, healthcare, energy, and more.

Subtopics
  • Crystallography and crystal defects
  • Phase transitions and thermodynamics of materials
  • Mechanical properties and failure analysis
  • Electrical, thermal, and optical properties
  • Nanomaterials and nanotechnology
  • Biomaterials for medical applications
  • Polymer science and engineering
  • Composites and hybrid materials
  • Corrosion and degradation of materials
  • Computational materials science and materials informatics
 

Materials science not elsewhere classified

This topic encompasses materials science research and developments that do not fall under the conventional categories or are emerging interdisciplinary fields. It includes new materials, unique properties, novel applications, or unusual combinations of structures and elements. Researchers in this area may explore cutting-edge technologies, such as metamaterials, biomimetic materials, and innovative composites that have not yet been fully classified within existing materials science subfields. This work often involves the convergence of different scientific principles, leading to pioneering solutions or enhancements in various technological spaces.

Subtopics
  • Metamaterials
  • Biomimetic materials
  • Novel composites
  • Advanced nanomaterials
  • Smart materials with multifunctional properties
  • Emergent phenomena in materials
  • Unconventional superconductors and magnetic materials
  • Hybrid organic-inorganic materials
  • Unexplored synthesis pathways and fabrication techniques
  • Interdisciplinary research innovations in materials science
 

Physics

Physics

Physics is the branch of science concerned with the nature and properties of matter and energy. It covers a wide range of phenomena, from the smallest subatomic particles to the largest galaxies. Physicists aim to understand how the universe behaves by studying the fundamental forces and laws of nature. This subject lays the foundation for many technological advancements and plays a critical role in understanding the world around us.

Subtopics
  • Mechanics: Motion, Forces, and Energy
  • Thermodynamics: Heat and Temperature
  • Electromagnetism: Electric and Magnetic Fields
  • Quantum Mechanics: Behavior of Subatomic Particles
  • Relativity: Space-time and Gravity
  • Optics: Light and Its Properties
  • Atomic Physics: Structure and Behavior of Atoms
  • Nuclear Physics: Nuclei and Nuclear Reactions
  • Condensed Matter Physics: Properties of Solids and Liquids
  • Astrophysics: Understanding Universe and Celestial Bodies
 

Applied physics

Applied physics is the study of the practical application of physical principles to solve real-world problems. It is an interdisciplinary field that bridges the gap between pure physics and engineering, leveraging fundamental physics concepts to develop new technologies, materials, and systems. Applied physicists work across a variety of sectors, including electronics, telecommunications, renewable energy, and materials science, often contributing to advances in areas such as semiconductor technology, photonics, and nanotechnology.

Subtopics
  • Semiconductor Physics: Study and development of semiconductor materials and devices, such as transistors and diodes.
  • Photonics: Application of physical principles to manipulate and utilize photons in technologies like lasers, fiber optics, and optical sensors.
  • Nanotechnology: Exploration and application of extremely small materials and devices, often at the atomic or molecular scale.
  • Medical Physics: Use of physics concepts to develop medical technologies and treatment modalities, such as MRI and radiation therapy.
  • Renewable Energy Technologies: Application of physics to improve technologies related to solar, wind, and other renewable energy sources.
  • Quantum Computing: Utilization of quantum mechanics principles to develop new computation methods and technologies.
  • Material Science: Study of the properties and applications of new materials, including their fabrication and testing for various applications.
 

Engineering physics

Engineering physics is an interdisciplinary field that bridges the gap between applied physics and engineering. It focuses on the application of physics principles to solve complex engineering problems and develop new technologies. This field combines theoretical aspects of physics with practical engineering skills, enabling the design and improvement of innovative devices, materials, and processes. Engineering physics is integral to advancements in areas such as electronics, renewable energy, telecommunications, and biotechnology.

Subtopics
  • Semiconductor Physics: Study of semiconductors and their applications in electronic devices such as transistors and diodes.
  • Quantum Mechanics in Engineering: Application of quantum mechanics principles to develop cutting-edge technologies in electronics and nanotechnology.
  • Thermodynamics and Heat Transfer: Understanding and application of energy conversion processes and the transfer of heat in engineering systems.
  • Optics and Photonics: Exploration of light properties and applications in developing lasers, fiber optics, and optical sensors.
  • Material Science and Engineering: Investigation of material properties and development of new materials with specific engineering applications.
  • Electromagnetics and Electrodynamics: Study and application of the behavior of electric and magnetic fields in technology.
  • Robotics and Control Systems: Engineering design and control of robotic systems, incorporating physics principles for precision and efficiency.
  • Computational Physics in Engineering: Use of computational methods and simulations to solve engineering problems based on physics models.
  • Acoustics in Engineering: Application of sound principles in developing audio systems, noise control, and acoustic materials.
 

Chemical physics

Chemical physics is an interdisciplinary subfield that blends principles of chemistry and physics to explore the physical properties and behavior of chemical systems. This area attempts to understand the fundamental interactions and forces at play in chemical reactions and processes, often focusing on the physical mechanisms behind chemical changes. Through the use of both theoretical approaches and sophisticated experimental techniques, chemical physicists seek to describe phenomena such as energy transfer, molecular dynamics, and quantum mechanics of chemical systems. The integration of these disciplines aids in the development of new materials, improved reaction processes, and the advancement of technologies in various applied sciences.

Subtopics
  • Quantum Chemistry: Study of quantum mechanics applied to chemical compounds.
  • Molecular Dynamics: Simulation of physical movements in molecules.
  • Thermodynamics in Chemical Systems: Exploration of energy transfer and thermodynamics in chemical reactions.
  • Spectroscopy: Techniques for studying the interaction of light with matter.
  • Reaction Kinetics: Analysis of the rates of chemical processes.
  • Solid-State Chemistry: Study of the properties and behavior of solid materials.
  • Surface Science: Investigation of physical and chemical phenomena that occur at the interface of two phases.
  • Statistical Mechanics in Chemistry: Application of statistical mechanics to chemical phenomena.
  • Computational Chemical Physics: Use of computer simulations to solve chemical physics problems.
 

Solid-state physics

Solid-state physics is a branch of physics that deals with the study of rigid matter, particularly the behavior of atoms in various solid materials. It focuses on understanding the properties of solid materials such as metals, semiconductors, and insulators. By exploring the atomic-scale interactions within these materials, solid-state physics aims to describe phenomena such as conductivity, magnetism, and superconductivity. This field forms the backbone of numerous technological advancements, including the development of transistors, microchips, and other electronic components.

Subtopics
  • Crystal Structure: Analysis of the ordered arrangement of atoms in solids and how these structures impact material properties.
  • Electronic Band Theory: Study of energy bands in solids that explain conduction and insulation behaviors.
  • Lattice Dynamics: Exploration of vibrations in a crystal lattice and their contribution to thermal properties.
  • Defects and Dislocations: Examination of imperfections in the atomic structure and their effects on material properties.
  • Magnetism in Solids: Investigation of magnetic properties resulting from electron spin and orbital motion.
  • Superconductivity: Study of materials that exhibit zero electrical resistance below a certain temperature.
  • Nanostructures and Amp; Low-dimensional Systems: Research into behavior and applications of materials at the nanoscale.
 

Environmental physics

Environmental physics is a branch of physics that focuses on the physical processes and phenomena occurring within the environment. It involves the application of physical concepts to understand the dynamics of ecosystems, the impact of human activities on the natural world, and the interactions between different environmental components, such as the atmosphere, hydrosphere, and lithosphere. This field is essential for addressing issues like climate change, pollution, and resource management, as it provides the scientific basis for developing sustainable solutions to environmental challenges.

Subtopics
  • Atmospheric physics: Study of the Earth's atmosphere, weather patterns, and climate systems.
  • Climate change physics: Exploration of the mechanisms and effects of global climate change.
  • Renewable energy: Examination of the principles behind solar, wind, and other sustainable energy sources.
  • Pollution and environmental contamination: Analysis of pollution sources, dispersion, and mitigation strategies.
  • Hydrological physics: Investigation of water cycle dynamics and their impact on ecosystems.
  • Geophysical processes: Understanding the physics of natural phenomena like earthquakes, volcanic activity, and erosion.
  • Ecosystem dynamics: Study of energy flow and material cycles within ecological systems.
 

Atmospheric physics

Atmospheric physics is a branch of meteorology and physics focusing on the study of the Earth's atmosphere and its processes. It involves the application of the principles of physics to understand the thermal, dynamical, radiative, and compositional features of the atmosphere. This field encompasses a range of phenomena including weather patterns, climate change, and atmospheric dynamics, utilizing both observational data and theoretical models to predict atmospheric behavior and understand the fundamental laws governing atmospheric processes.

Subtopics
  • Radiative Transfer: Study of how radiation is absorbed, emitted, and scattered in the atmosphere.
  • Cloud Physics: Investigations into the formation, composition, and dynamics of clouds and their role in weather systems.
  • Climate Dynamics: Analysis of the large-scale processes that determine global climate patterns and variability.
  • Atmospheric Thermodynamics: Examination of the thermal properties of the atmosphere and temperature-related phenomena.
  • Atmospheric Dynamics: Study of air motion, focusing on the forces and energy exchange that drive weather systems.
  • Atmospheric Chemistry: Exploration of the chemical composition of the atmosphere and the reactions that occur within it, impacting air quality and climate.
  • Planetary Atmospheres: Comparative study of atmospheres on other planets to understand their structure and dynamics.
  • Synoptic Meteorology: Analysis of large-scale weather systems and the interpretation of weather maps and models.
  • Atmospheric Boundary Layer: Research into the lowest part of the atmosphere where its interaction with the surface affects weather and climate.
  • Remote Sensing: Techniques for gathering atmospheric data using satellite or radar technologies.
 

Marine physics

Marine physics is a branch of physics that deals with the study of physical conditions and processes within the marine environment, including the ocean, seas, and coastal regions. It involves the exploration of phenomena such as wave dynamics, ocean currents, heat transfer, and sound transmission underwater. By utilizing principles of fluid dynamics, thermodynamics, and acoustics, marine physics helps in understanding the interactions between the ocean and atmosphere, the impact of climate change on marine systems, and the mechanics that drive marine ecosystems. This field is critical for applications in marine navigation, offshore construction, and environmental conservation.

Subtopics
  • Oceanography: Study of physical and chemical properties of the ocean.
  • Wave Dynamics: Analysis of wave formation, propagation, and energy.
  • Ocean Currents: Examination of large-scale movement of water masses.
  • Underwater Acoustics: Study of sound transmission and reception under the sea.
  • Marine Thermodynamics: Exploration of heat transfer processes in the ocean.
  • Tides and Sea Level: Investigation of tidal movements and sea level changes.
  • Coastal Processes: Study of erosion, sediment transport, and deposition in coastal areas.
  • Marine Hydrodynamics: Examination of fluid motion and interactions in marine contexts.
  • Climate-Ocean Interaction: Analysis of how marine physics contributes to climate change studies.
 

Mathematical & theoretical physics

Mathematical and theoretical physics involves the use of advanced mathematical methods and theoretical frameworks to understand and predict physical phenomena. It seeks to provide a rigorous quantitative foundation for physics concepts and experimental results, often addressing fundamental aspects of the natural world using abstract and complex mathematics. The field bridges pure mathematics with experimental physics, focusing on formulating theories that describe the universe at very large and very small scales, such as general relativity and quantum mechanics. Theoretical physicists develop models and simulations to explain observations and guide experimental research.

Subtopics
  • Quantum mechanics and field theory
  • General relativity and gravitational physics
  • String theory and quantum gravity
  • Statistical mechanics and thermodynamics
  • Computational and mathematical modeling in physics
  • Symmetry and group theory in physical systems
  • Non-linear dynamics and chaos theory
  • Theoretical cosmology and astrophysics
  • Gauge theories and particle physics
  • Topological and geometric methods in physics
 

Electromagnetism

Electromagnetism is a fundamental branch of physics that studies the electromagnetic force, a type of physical interaction that occurs between electrically charged particles. It encompasses various phenomena responsible for electricity, magnetism, and electromagnetic fields. Electromagnetism explains how these fields interact with matter, providing the foundation for understanding concepts such as electric currents, magnetic forces, and electromagnetic waves, including light. This area of study is critical for the development of numerous technologies like motors, generators, communication systems, and medical imaging devices.

Subtopics
  • Electric Charge and Coulomb's Law
  • Electric Field and Electric Potential
  • Gauss's Law and Its Applications
  • Capacitance and Dielectrics
  • Electric Current, Resistance, and Ohm's Law
  • Magnetic Field and Magnetic Force
  • Ampre's Law and Its Applications
  • Faraday's Law of Electromagnetic Induction
  • Maxwell's Equations
  • Electromagnetic Waves and Spectrum
  • Practical Applications: Generators, Motors, and Transformers
  • Modern Technologies: Wireless Communication, MRI, and Electromagnetic Compatibility
 

Quantum mechanics

Quantum mechanics is a fundamental theory in physics that describes the physical properties of nature at the smallest scales, such as atoms and subatomic particles. Unlike classical mechanics, quantum mechanics deals with probabilities and uncertainties, integrating principles such as wave-particle duality, quantization of energy, and entanglement. It offers profound insights into the behavior and interaction of matter and energy, challenging traditional notions of determinism and offering a framework for understanding the universe's fundamental building blocks.

Subtopics
  • Wave-Particle Duality: The concept that every quantum entity exhibits both particle and wave properties.
  • Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle: The principle stating that certain pairs of properties, such as position and momentum, cannot be simultaneously measured with arbitrary precision.
  • Quantum Entanglement: A phenomenon where particles become interconnected and the state of one instantly influences the state of another, regardless of distance.
  • Schrdinger Equation: A differential equation that describes how quantum states evolve over time.
  • Quantum Tunneling: The process by which particles pass through potential barriers, even when they seemingly lack the energy to do so.
  • Superposition Principle: The principle that a quantum system can exist in multiple states at once until observed.
  • Quantum Computing: An area of study focused on developing computers based on quantum-mechanical principles.
  • Quantum Field Theory: An extension of quantum mechanics that combines classical field theory, special relativity, and quantum mechanics.
 

Computational physics

Computational physics is an interdisciplinary field that leverages the power of computational techniques and algorithms to solve and analyze complex problems in physics. It bridges the gap between theoretical physics and experimental work by providing numerical solutions to physical problems that are often not solvable analytically. This approach is crucial in simulating physical systems, modeling experimental setups, and predicting phenomena under various conditions, thus offering deep insights that may not be accessible through traditional methods alone.

Subtopics
  • Numerical methods in physics: Techniques such as finite difference methods, Monte Carlo simulations, and spectral methods used to approximate solutions to physical equations.
  • Simulation and modeling: Utilizing computers to recreate and analyze the behavior of physical systems like molecular dynamics simulations, astrophysical simulations, and more.
  • High-performance computing: Leveraging supercomputers and parallel processing to handle large-scale computations and simulations.
  • Quantum computing for physics: Exploring the application of quantum algorithms and quantum computational models to solve problems in physics.
  • Visualization techniques: Using graphical representations to interpret and understand complex data and simulations in physics.
  • Algorithm development: Innovating new algorithms specific to solving physics-related problems more efficiently and accurately.
 

Medical physics

Medical physics is an interdisciplinary field that applies the principles and concepts of physics to medicine for the purpose of healthcare. It involves the application of physics-based techniques and theories to diagnose, treat, and understand medical conditions. Medical physicists work in clinical environments to improve the safety and efficacy of medical technologies, particularly in imaging and radiation therapy. This field also emphasizes research and development of new medical technologies, aiming to advance the precision and effectiveness of medical treatments and diagnostics.

Subtopics
  • Diagnostic Imaging: Techniques and technologies for creating visual representations of the interior of a body for clinical analysis, including X-ray, MRI, CT scans, and ultrasound.
  • Radiation Therapy: Use of high-energy radiation to treat diseases, primarily cancer, and related protocols and safety measures.
  • Nuclear Medicine: The use of radioactive substances in diagnosis and treatment, focusing on the use of radiopharmaceuticals.
  • Health Physics: Radiation safety and the protection of people from harmful effects of radiation while making it possible to benefit from its utilization.
  • Biomedical Optics: Use of light and optics in the development and application of instrumentation for medical diagnostics and treatments.
  • Dosimetry: Study and measurement of the absorbed dose delivered by ionizing radiation for effective treatment planning and safety assurance.
  • Medical Device Physics: Design and optimization of various medical devices, including linear accelerators and imaging equipment.
  • Image Processing and Analysis: Advanced computational methods for enhancing, interpreting, and understanding medical images for better diagnostics and patient management.
  • Emerging Technologies: Research and development of new technologies and techniques, such as proton therapy and personalized medicine approaches.
 

Radiation physics

Radiation physics is a branch of physics that studies the properties and behaviors of radiation and its interactions with matter. It encompasses a wide range of radiation types, including electromagnetic radiation such as X-rays and gamma rays, as well as particle radiation like alpha and beta particles. This field is crucial for understanding how radiation can be both beneficial, such as in medical imaging and cancer treatment, as well as harmful, like in radiation damage and radiation protection. Radiation physics involves understanding the principles of nuclear decay, the behavior of particles and waves, and the mechanisms of energy transfer and absorption.

Subtopics
  • Types of Radiation: Study of different forms of radiation, including alpha, beta, gamma, X-rays, and neutron radiation.
  • Radiation Interaction with Matter: Examination of how various types of radiation interact with different materials, including absorption, scattering, and ionization processes.
  • Radiation Measurement and Detection: Techniques and instruments used to measure and detect radiation levels, such as Geiger counters and scintillation detectors.
  • Radiation Dosimetry: Study of dose measurement, dose distribution, and calculation of absorbed dose in various media.
  • Applications of Radiation: Exploration of the use of radiation in medical treatments (e.g., radiotherapy), imaging (e.g., CT scans), industrial applications, and scientific research.
  • Radiation Safety and Protection: Principles and practices involved in protecting people and the environment from the harmful effects of radiation, including shielding, exposure limits, and regulatory policies.
  • Radiobiology: Investigation of the biological effects of radiation on living tissues and organisms, including DNA damage and repair mechanisms.
  • Nuclear Decay Processes: Understanding of radioactive decay mechanisms, half-life calculations, and decay chains.
  • Radiation Transport and Shielding: Modeling and simulation of radiation transport through different mediums and the design of materials and structures to block or reduce exposure.
 

Optical physics

Optical physics is a branch of physics that focuses on the study of light and its interactions with matter. It encompasses a wide range of phenomena including reflection, refraction, diffraction, interference, and polarization. Optical physics is fundamental to the understanding of both classical and quantum systems and has applications in various fields such as telecommunications, medical imaging, and quantum computing. Researchers in this area investigate the behavior of light at both macroscopic and microscopic levels, developing technologies like lasers, fiber optics, and optical sensors.

Subtopics
  • Geometrical Optics: Study of light propagation in terms of rays, including reflection and refraction.
  • Wave Optics: Examination of phenomena that occur due to the wave nature of light, such as interference and diffraction.
  • Quantum Optics: Exploration of the quantum properties of light and its interaction with matter at the quantum level.
  • Photonics: Use of light to perform functions typically managed by electronics, including information transmission and processing.
  • Nonlinear Optics: Investigation of how light behaves in nonlinear media where the response depends on the light intensity.
  • Laser Physics: Study and development of lasers, focusing on their mechanisms and various applications.
  • Optical Materials: Research into materials used in optical technologies, focusing on their properties and advances in optical functionalities.
 

Laser physics

Laser physics is a branch of physics that deals with the theory and practical implementation of lasers. A laser is a device that emits light through a process of optical amplification based on the stimulated emission of electromagnetic radiation. Laser physics explores the underlying concepts of quantum mechanics and electromagnetism to understand how laser devices operate, the properties of the laser light they generate, and applications of lasers in various fields like medicine, communication, industry, and scientific research. The discipline covers topics ranging from the basic principles of laser generation and amplification to advanced laser technologies and their uses.

Subtopics
  • Principles of laser operation
  • Types of lasers (gas, solid-state, semiconductor, etc.)
  • Quantum mechanics of laser action
  • Laser modes and resonator design
  • Applications of lasers in medicine
  • Laser applications in telecommunications
  • Industrial and military applications of lasers
  • Nonlinear optics in lasers
  • Laser safety and standards
  • High-power and ultrafast lasers
 

Nuclear & particle physics

Nuclear and particle physics is a branch of physics that studies the fundamental particles of the universe and the forces that govern their interactions. This field explores the constitution, behavior, and interactions of atomic nuclei, as well as subatomic particles such as protons, neutrons, electrons, quarks, and neutrinos. Researchers use both theoretical models and experimental methods, often involving complex equipment like particle accelerators and detectors, to uncover the laws governing these particles. The discoveries in this area not only enhance our understanding of the universe at the smallest scales but also have practical applications in areas such as energy production, medical treatments, and the development of new materials.

Subtopics
  • Atomic nuclei: Composition, structure, and stability of atomic nuclei, nuclear forces, and nuclear reactions.
  • Fundamental interactions: Weak, strong, electromagnetic, and gravity forces as they pertain to particle behavior.
  • Particle accelerators: Technology and techniques used to accelerate and collide particles at high speeds to observe fundamental interactions.
  • Quantum chromodynamics: Study of the strong interaction between quarks and gluons.
  • Standard Model of particle physics: Framework describing fundamental particles (quarks, leptons) and their interactions.
  • Beyond the Standard Model: Theoretical developments, such as supersymmetry, string theory, and hypotheses about dark matter and dark energy.
  • Experimental techniques: Methods for detecting and measuring subatomic particles, including detectors and spectrometers.
  • Applications of nuclear physics: Use of nuclear reactions for energy (nuclear power) and health (radiotherapy), as well as in military and space technologies.
 

Acoustics

Acoustics is the branch of physics that deals with the study of sound, including its generation, transmission, and effects. It encompasses a wide range of phenomena and applications, from the fundamental understanding of sound waves in different media (such as air, water, and solids) to the practical engineering of audio equipment, architectural acoustics, and noise control. Acoustics plays a crucial role in various fields, including music, telecommunications, medicine, and environmental science, helping to improve sound quality in different environments and solve issues related to noise pollution and soundproofing.

Subtopics
  • Sound Wave Propagation: Study of how sound travels in different media and environments.
  • Architectural Acoustics: Design of buildings and spaces to optimize sound quality and minimize noise.
  • Audio Engineering: Development and improvement of equipment and technologies for recording and reproducing sound.
  • Psychoacoustics: Exploration of human perception of sound and its psychological effects.
  • Underwater Acoustics: Investigation of sound behavior underwater, crucial for naval and marine biology applications.
  • Noise Control: Techniques and technologies for reducing unwanted sound in various settings.
  • Musical Acoustics: Study of the physical processes underlying musical instrument sound production.
  • Biomedical Acoustics: Use of sound waves in medical applications, such as ultrasound imaging and therapy.
 

Physics not elsewhere classified

This topic covers areas of physics that do not fall within traditional categories or well-defined subfields. It serves as a catch-all classification for emerging, interdisciplinary, or unconventional areas that are either in the early stages of exploration or involve innovative approaches that extend beyond classical boundaries. This includes avant-garde theories, novel experimental techniques, and unique applications of physical principles that evolve through time as the field of physics continues to expand and integrate with other scientific domains. The undefined nature of this category enables researchers to explore diverse phenomena that challenge standard classifications, fostering advancements in knowledge and technology.

Subtopics
  • Quantum biology: The application of quantum mechanics to biological systems and processes.
  • Non-linear dynamics: Studies focused on systems exhibiting non-linear behavior not covered by classical physics.
  • Advanced materials: Investigation of new states of matter or exotic materials with unusual properties.
  • Theoretical models: Novel theoretical frameworks that do not fit the standard model or existing categories.
  • Interdisciplinary physics: Cross-disciplinary studies that integrate concepts from various fields to explore complex systems.
  • Experimental innovations: Development and application of novel experimental techniques that open new avenues for research.
  • Anomalous phenomena: Study of unexplained physical phenomena requiring new theoretical insights.
  • Historical and philosophical aspects: Exploration of the impact and evolution of unconventional theories in the historical and philosophical context of physics.
  • Applications in emerging technologies: Implementation of non-traditional physics concepts in emerging technological advancements, such as quantum computing or nanotechnology.
 

Forensic & archaeological sciences

Forensic & archaeological sciences

Forensic and archaeological sciences intersect the fields of physical sciences to apply scientific principles and techniques to the analysis of evidence from crime scenes, historical artifacts, and other materials of forensic or historical interest. These sciences involve the application of chemistry, biology, physics, and geology to uncover details about past events, solve crimes, and ascertain facts about historical human activity. Techniques like radiocarbon dating, DNA analysis, and materials characterization are commonly used to draw conclusions in legal contexts or historical studies.

Subtopics
  • Forensic Techniques in Crime Scene Investigation: Involving the collection, preservation, and analysis of physical evidence.
  • Archaeological Excavation and Dating Methods: Techniques such as stratigraphy and radiocarbon dating to establish historical timelines.
  • Forensic Anthropology and Osteology: The study of human remains to determine identity, cause of death, or historical significance.
  • Material Analysis and Conservation: Examining objects to understand their composition, origin, and how best to preserve them.
  • DNA Analysis and Bioarchaeology: Using genetic material to draw information about past populations and solve modern forensic cases.
  • Remote Sensing and Geophysical Methods: Non-invasive techniques to detect and map archaeological sites or forensic evidence.
  • Legal Implications and Ethical Considerations: Understanding the legal frameworks and ethical guidelines governing forensic and archaeological operations.
 

Forensic science

Forensic science is the application of a broad range of scientific principles and techniques to answer questions of interest to a legal system. This may be in relation to a crime or a civil action. Forensic scientists collect, preserve, and analyze scientific evidence during the course of an investigation. While some forensics professionals visit the scene of the crime to collect the evidence themselves, others occupy a laboratory role, performing analysis on objects brought to them by other individuals.

Subtopics
  • DNA analysis and profiling
  • Fingerprint analysis
  • Bloodstain pattern analysis
  • Toxicology
  • Digital forensics
  • Trace evidence analysis
  • Ballistics and firearms examination
  • Forensic anthropology
  • Forensic pathology
  • Forensic odontology
 

Archaeological science

Archaeological science, often referred to as archaeometry, is the application of scientific techniques and methodologies to analyze and interpret archaeological findings. This interdisciplinary field combines elements of chemistry, physics, biology, and earth sciences to provide insights into ancient human activities, cultural practices, and environmental conditions. By employing advanced technologies such as radiocarbon dating, DNA analysis, and isotope geochemistry, archaeological science enhances our understanding of past human civilizations and contributes to the preservation and management of cultural heritage.

Subtopics
  • Radiocarbon Dating: Techniques for determining the age of organic materials.
  • Isotope Analysis: The study of isotopic ratios to infer dietary, climate, and migration patterns.
  • DNA Analysis: Extraction and examination of ancient DNA to study genetic relationships and evolution.
  • Paleoenvironmental Reconstruction: Techniques for reconstructing past environments using botanical, faunal, and sedimentary evidence.
  • Artifact Analysis: Scientific examination and characterization of materials used in ancient artifacts.
  • Geoarchaeology: The study of geological processes to understand human-landscape interactions.
  • Conservation Science: Methods for preserving archaeological findings and preventing deterioration.
  • Remote Sensing and GIS: Techniques for archaeological site discovery and landscape analysis using satellite imagery and spatial data.
  • Thermoluminescence Dating: A method for determining the age of ceramics and other materials by measuring trapped electrons.
 

Forensic & archaeological sciences not elsewhere classified

This field encompasses a variety of specialized techniques and approaches that do not fall under the more commonly recognized categories of forensic and archaeological analysis. These methods might include innovative scientific techniques, unique analytical methods, and cutting-edge technologies designed to uncover insights from both contemporary and ancient materials from crime scenes, archaeological sites, or other contexts. The interdisciplinary nature of this topic often involves the integration of knowledge from various scientific domains to solve complex questions related to human history and modern-day legal investigations.

Subtopics
  • Development and application of new analytical technologies for forensic investigations
  • Interdisciplinary approaches combining chemistry, biology, and physics to analyze archaeological artifacts
  • Non-invasive imaging techniques for examining historical sites and remains
  • Emerging fields within forensic anthropology and bioarchaeology
  • Novel methods for dating and authenticating archaeological findings
  • The role of digital forensics and information technology in the field
  • Environmental forensics focusing on tracing pollutants and understanding ancient ecosystems through residues
  • The use of isotopic analysis in tracing geographical origins and migrations in archaeological contexts
 

Astronomy

Astronomy

Astronomy is the scientific study of celestial objects, space, and the universe as a whole. It involves observing and analyzing phenomena outside Earth's atmosphere, unraveling the mysteries of planets, stars, galaxies, and the cosmic microwave background radiation. Modern astronomy combines a range of methodologies from across the physical sciences to understand both the origin and evolution of the universe, as well as our place within it. This discipline employs theoretical models, simulations, and both ground-based and space-borne telescopes to gather data in various wavelengths of light, thereby probing the structure and dynamics of the universe at different scales.

Subtopics
  • Observational Astronomy: Techniques for gathering data from celestial objects using telescopes and various detectors.
  • Theoretical Astronomy: Development and analysis of models to interpret observational data and predict celestial phenomena.
  • Cosmology: Study of the universe's origin, evolution, structure, and ultimate fate.
  • Stellar Astronomy: Examination of stars, including their formation, composition, and life cycle.
  • Galactic Astronomy: Focus on the structure and components of galaxies, including our own Milky Way.
  • Planetary Astronomy: Exploration of planets, moons, and planetary systems both within and beyond our solar system.
  • Astrophysics: Intersection of physics and astronomy to understand the physical properties and behaviors of celestial bodies.
  • Radio Astronomy: Study of space phenomena through radio waves.
  • Astronomical instrumentation: Development of technology and instruments to enhance astronomical observation and analysis.
 

Astrophysics

Astrophysics is the branch of astronomy that employs the principles of physics and chemistry to understand how stars, planets, and galaxies form, evolve, and emit light. It involves the study of various celestial bodies and phenomena occurring in the universe, attempting to describe their nature, origin, and future. Astrophysics combines theoretical models and empirical data gathered using telescopes and other scientific instruments to unlock the mysteries of the cosmos, ranging from the small scale of particles to the large-scale structure of the universe.

Subtopics
  • Stellar Dynamics and Evolution: Study of how stars, as they age, undergo changes in their structure and properties, leading to phenomena such as supernovae and black hole formation.
  • Cosmology: Examination of the universe's large scale structure, its origins, its history, and its future, including theories about the Big Bang and cosmic expansion.
  • Galactic Astronomy: Focus on the formation and evolution of galaxies, interactions between galaxies, and the role of dark matter and dark energy.
  • High-Energy Astrophysics: Study of celestial phenomena that occur in high energy regimes, including gamma-ray bursts, quasars, and X-ray binary stars.
  • Planetary Science: Investigation of planets, moons, and planetary systems, both within our solar system and in extrasolar systems, including their formation, climatology, and geology.
  • Computational Astrophysics: Use of advanced computational methods and simulations to model complex astrophysical processes and systems.
  • Exoplanetary Science: Study of planets beyond our solar system, eager to understand their atmospheres, composition, and potential for hosting life.
 

Space & planetary sciences

Space and planetary sciences is a branch of astronomy that focuses on the study of celestial bodies within our solar system and beyond. It involves the exploration and characterization of planets, moons, asteroids, comets, and other objects in space to understand their composition, dynamics, atmospheres, and potential for hosting life. This field utilizes a variety of methods including telescopic observations, spacecraft missions, and computer simulations to answer fundamental questions about the origin and evolution of planets and their potential habitability.

Subtopics
  • Planetary geology: Study of the structure and composition of planetary surfaces and interiors.
  • Atmospheric science: Investigation of atmospheric properties and dynamics of planets and moons.
  • Astrobiology: Research into the potential for life elsewhere in the universe and the conditions that support it.
  • Solar system formation: Examination of the processes that led to the formation of the solar system.
  • Exoplanetary studies: Exploration of planets orbiting stars outside our solar system.
  • Space missions and technology: Development and application of spacecraft and instruments for planetary exploration.
 

Space science

Space science is a multidisciplinary field that studies the universe beyond Earth's atmosphere, encompassing various phenomena, celestial bodies, and the underlying physical principles governing them. This area of science covers a wide range of topics, including the study of planets, stars, galaxies, and the overall structure of the cosmos. It involves the use of telescopic observations, space missions, and theoretical modeling to understand the composition, behavior, and evolution of different celestial entities. Space science seeks to answer fundamental questions about the origin and development of the universe, the nature of dark matter and dark energy, and the potential for extraterrestrial life. It contributes vital knowledge that aids in navigating space missions and evaluating the impact of cosmic events on Earth's environment.

Subtopics
  • Planetary Science: Study of planets, moons, and planetary systems, including their formation, evolution, and potential habitability.
  • Stellar Astronomy: Examination of stars, their life cycles, and the processes occurring within and surrounding them.
  • Galactic Astronomy: Analysis of galaxies, their structures, dynamics, and the role they play in the broader universe.
  • Cosmology: Investigation of the universe as a whole, including its origin, large-scale structures, and eventual fate.
  • Astrobiology: Exploration of the possibility of life beyond Earth, including the study of extremophiles and biosignatures.
  • Exoplanet Studies: Research on planets orbiting stars outside our solar system, focusing on their composition, atmospheres, and potential for hosting life.
  • Astrophysics: Application of physical laws and theories to understand how celestial objects interact and evolve over time.
  • Space Exploration Technologies: Development of tools and techniques for observing space, traveling to celestial bodies, and deploying space probes and telescopes.
  • Astrochemistry: Study of chemical elements and molecules in space, including their formation and interaction in different astronomical environments.
 

Planetary science

Planetary science is a branch of astronomy that focuses on the study of planets, moons, and planetary systems, particularly those of the Solar System and the processes that form them. It involves analyzing the composition, dynamics, formation, and potential life-related aspects of these celestial bodies. By using various methods, including observational and theoretical approaches, as well as physical and chemical modeling, planetary science seeks to understand the origins and evolution of planets and their atmospheres, surfaces, and interiors.

Subtopics
  • Planetary geology: Study of planet surfaces, structures, and geological processes.
  • Atmospheric science: Analysis of planetary atmospheres, weather, and climate systems.
  • Astrobiology: Exploration of life potential beyond Earth and the conditions necessary for life.
  • Planetary formation: Research on the formation and development of planets and their satellites.
  • Comparative planetology: Comparative study of different planets to understand their similarities and differences.
  • Planetary magnetism: Investigation of planetary magnetic fields and their interactions with solar winds.
  • Exoplanet studies: Exploration of planets beyond the Solar System and their potential habitability.
 

Solar & solar terrestrial physics

Solar and solar terrestrial physics explore the physical phenomena occurring within the Sun and how these affect the surrounding solar system, especially Earth's environment. This field studies the Sun's structure, dynamics, and activity, including solar flares, sunspots, and coronal mass ejections. It also examines interactions between solar activity and Earth's magnetosphere, ionosphere, and climate system. By understanding these interactions, scientists can better predict space weather events that impact satellites, communication systems, and power grids on Earth.

Subtopics
  • Solar Structure and Composition
  • Solar Atmosphere (Photosphere, Chromosphere, Corona)
  • Solar Dynamics (Oscillations, Differential Rotation)
  • Solar Cycle and Activity (Sunspots, Solar Flares)
  • Solar Wind and Heliosphere
  • Coronal Mass Ejections
  • Solar-Terrestrial Interactions
  • Space Weather and its Effects on Earth
  • Magnetosphere and Ionospheric Research
  • Solar and Cosmic Ray Interactions with the Atmosphere
  • Impact on Satellite and Communication Systems
  • Climatic Effects of Solar Variability
 

Astronomy observation

Astronomy observation involves the practice of examining celestial objects and phenomena by collecting and analyzing data, primarily through optical instruments like telescopes, as well as using other parts of the electromagnetic spectrum. It's a fundamental aspect of astronomy that allows researchers to gather evidence about objects such as planets, stars, galaxies, and cosmic events, enhancing our understanding of the universes structure and development. These observations can be conducted from Earths surface or through space-based instruments, each offering unique advantages in capturing detailed and accurate astronomical data.

Subtopics
  • Telescope Technology: Different types of telescopes (optical, radio, space-based) and advancements.
  • Observational Techniques: Methods for observing celestial objects, such as spectroscopy and astrometry.
  • Data Collection and Analysis: Use of software and statistical tools to interpret observational data.
  • Light Pollution: Challenges and solutions in astronomical observation due to artificial lighting.
  • Key Observatories: Prominent Earth-based and space observatories and their contributions.
  • Citizen Science: Public involvement in astronomical observation projects.
  • Historical Observations: Impact of early astronomical discoveries and techniques on modern science.
 

Astronomy theory

Astronomy theory involves the formulation and study of fundamental principles that describe the universe and its various phenomena. It encompasses a wide range of concepts from the macroscopic scales of galaxies and black holes to the microscopic scales of subatomic particles and their roles in cosmic events. Theoretical astronomy aims to understand the laws governing celestial bodies and the universe, often utilizing mathematical models and simulations to predict and explain observations. It plays a crucial role in advancing our knowledge of the cosmos and informs observational and experimental approaches in astronomy.

Subtopics
  • General relativity and its applications in gravitational theory
  • Quantum mechanics in astrophysics
  • Dark matter and dark energy theories
  • Cosmology and the expansion of the universe
  • Theoretical models of stellar evolution
  • Black holes, singularity theory, and event horizons
  • Galaxy formation and dynamics
  • Astroparticle physics and cosmic ray theory
  • Exoplanetary systems and planet formation theories
  • Computational astrophysics and simulation methods
 

Astronomy not elsewhere classified

This area of astronomy encompasses a broad range of topics that do not fit into the traditional categories such as planetary science, stellar astronomy, cosmology, or galactic astronomy. It includes emerging fields, interdisciplinary studies, innovative methods, and unique astronomical phenomena that require specialized focus or do not conform to standard classifications. Researchers and scholars in this area push the boundaries of our understanding of the universe by exploring unconventional questions, employing novel technologies, or integrating insights from other scientific disciplines.

Subtopics
  • Exoplanet discovery and characterization using unconventional methods
  • Study of dark matter and dark energy through innovative research approaches
  • Development of new astronomical instrumentation and observational techniques
  • Multi-messenger astronomy, including the study of neutrinos and gravitational waves
  • Interdisciplinary astronomical studies involving quantum physics or biology
  • Exploration of unusual astronomical phenomena such as fast radio bursts
  • Advancement in computational astronomy and data analysis techniques
  • Historical and philosophical perspectives on unconventional astronomical ideas
 

Geology

Geology

Geology is the scientific study of the Earth, including its composition, structure, physical properties, and the processes that shape it. This branch of physical sciences encompasses the examination of rocks, minerals, and the dynamic forces that have sculpted the planet over billions of years. Geologists strive to understand Earth's history and its formation, exploring topics like plate tectonics, earthquakes, volcanic activity, and the formation of mountains. Geology also investigates the natural resources contained within the Earths crust, including minerals, fossil fuels, and groundwater.

Subtopics
  • Mineralogy: The study of minerals, their structure, properties, and classification.
  • Petrology: The examination of rocks and the conditions under which they form.
  • Paleontology: The study of fossils and the reconstruction of past life on Earth.
  • Stratigraphy: The analysis of rock layers and layering, essential for understanding Earth's chronological history.
  • Structural Geology: The study of Earth's structures and the forces that cause them, like faults and folds.
  • Geophysics: The application of physics to understand Earths interior and its physical processes.
  • Economic Geology: Focused on materials that can be used for economic and/or industrial purposes, including ore deposits and fossil fuels.
  • Geochemistry: The study of Earth's chemical composition and the chemical processes that occur within it.
  • Volcanology: The study of volcanoes, lava, magma, and related geological, geophysical, and geochemical phenomena.
  • Seismology: The scientific study of earthquakes and the propagation of elastic waves through Earth.
